Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Latitudinal variation in invasive plant-herbivore interactions and implications for invasion success
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent studies with invasive species have revealed that evolution plays an important role in the successful invasion of new habitats. For plant species involved in continent-wide invasions, the expectation is that the well known north-south increase in the number of herbivore species should favor the rapid evolution of increased resistance to herbivores at lower latitudes. This prediction will be tested using the common reed, Phragmites australis. The common reed is widely distributed across European and North American marshes; in the past 100 years a European variety of this species has invaded and rapidly spread throughout North America. The first objective is to test whether the common reed has undergone rapid evolution to form a north-south gradient in traits associated with anti-herbivore defense. The second objective is to quantify differences in plant defenses between native and invasive varieties of the common reed that occur together in the same marshes and on separate continents, and to evaluate how these differences may affect invader success.

This will be the first study to test whether herbivores influence the evolution and the invasion success of invasive species at the scale of whole continents. This research will provide invaluable data regarding the potential negative effects that the invasive common reed variety is having on the less common varieties that are native to North America. The PIs will provide research experience, mentorship and training for two graduate and up to four undergraduate students. The PIs will also participate in a variety of programs that promote undergraduate research and public awareness of the detrimental effects of invasive species.

Project Outcomes Report

  • Award Title: NSF Ecological Studies Grant. Collaborative Research: Latitudinal variation in invasive plant-herbivore interactions and implications for invasion success
  • Federal Award ID: DEB-1049914
  • Report Submission Period: 03/01/20111 to 02/28/2016

Outcomes report:

Recent studies have revealed that evolution plays an important role in the successful invasion of new habitats. For plants involved in continent-wide invasions, the expectation is that the well known north-south increase in the number of herbivore species should favor the rapid evolution of increased resistance to herbivores as you move from higher to lower latitudes. This prediction was tested using Phragmites australis. Common reed is widely distributed across European and North American marshes, but in the past 100 years a European genotype of this species has invaded and rapidly spread throughout North America. The first objective of this project involved testing whether common reed has undergone rapid evolution to form a north-south gradient in anti-herbivore defense traits. The second objective involved quantifying differences in plant defenses between native and invasive varieties of common reed that occur together in the same marshes and on separate continents, and evaluate how these differences may affect invader success.

We conducted field surveys of native and invasive common reed along a transect from southern Florida to New Brunswick.. A corresponding survey of native reed in Europe (from southern Portugal to Norway) was also performed. As predicted, we found that native common reeds on both continents suffered greater levels of herbivory at low as compared to high latitudes. Corresponding studies in well-controlled garden plots in Louisiana and RI confirmed that these latitudinal differences in herbivory and defense were genetically based. Clearly, native reeds have adapted to environmental conditions related to latitude (e.g., climate). In contrast, invasive reeds in marshes of North America suffer low levels of herbivory irrespective of latitude. This may explain why invasive reeds do well in North America – to some degree, they have escaped their herbivores relative to native reeds. Interestingly, the difference in herbivory between native and invasive reeds is much greater at southern latitudes suggesting that if herbivores are important to the survival of these plants, as the data suggests, then invasion success is likely to be greater in the south than the north. In corresponding garden studies, invasive reeds show evidence of being adapted to the environmental conditions associated with the latitude from which those plants were collected. This finding demonstrates that invasive reeds have evolved in the roughly 150 years since arriving in NA in response to the latitudinal variability in herbivore pressure and/or the local environment. Furthermore, replicated studies in Louisiana and RI gardens indicate that genotypes of invasive reeds are more flexible (plastic) in response to changes in the environment (e.g., different garden locations) than genotypes of the native reeds.
